title: Anal Fissure Not Responding to Conservative Therapy
setup_script: A 34-year-old man reports severe pain and bleeding during defecation for 3 months. He has tried fiber supplements and topical lidocaine without relief. Examination reveals a posterior midline fissure with sentinel pile and increased sphincter tone.

dynamic_flow.trigger: Take focused history on bowel habits, trauma, and risk factors such as constipation or Crohn's disease.
Perform careful anorectal exam confirming chronic posterior fissure; check for sentinel tag and hypertrophic papilla.
Discuss initial management with fiber, sitz baths, topical nifedipine or diltiazem, and nitroglycerin ointment; ensure patient compliance.
Since conservative therapy failed, explain options: botulinum toxin injection versus lateral internal sphincterotomy (LIS).
Counsel patient on risks and benefits of LIS, including risk of minor incontinence; obtain informed consent.
Arrange preoperative evaluation and plan for outpatient surgery.
Perform LIS under regional anesthesia; divide internal sphincter partially to lower pressure while preserving continence.
Inspect fissure site for healing potential; avoid overcutting to reduce risk of incontinence.
Postoperative management: recommend sitz baths, stool softeners, and analgesia; monitor for urinary retention.
Advise patient to maintain high-fiber diet and adequate hydration to prevent recurrence.
Schedule follow-up to assess healing and continence; treat any residual fissure with topical agents.
Educate patient on warning signs of infection or recurrence requiring reassessment.

critical_decision_points: Accurate diagnosis of chronic fissure and failure of medical therapy.
Decision to perform lateral internal sphincterotomy and discussion of risks.
Proper surgical technique to divide internal sphincter without causing incontinence.
Patient education on diet, bowel habits, and follow-up.
